document.text: Wednesday, October 16, has been designated as Regis.ra.ion Day for all men 21 to 35, inclusive, under the draft law enacted by Congress and signed by the President. The regular election precincts will be us ed as registration places, with the election officials acting as officials.  Charles Crawley, secretary of the Appomattox county electoral board, will attend a meeting next week in Richmond, when details of the regis tration procedure will be explained to the election officials.

document.text: Tuesday of this week, Sunset at Appomattox, a documentary film,, produced in Hollywood, had its pre miere before a blue ribbon list of dignataries in Lynchiburg. Nearly 200 saw the advance showing, and came away thrilled at the splendid reproduction of the events of April 9, 1865 at Appomattox. At a dinner at the Virginian Ho tel preceding the showing, Represen tative W. M. Abbitt was toastmaster. Fred Helsaibeck, vice-mayor of the City of Lynchburg, gave the invoca tion. Distinguished guests, including educators and historians, were intro duced. Major-General U. S. Grant, III, grandson of Ulyssis S. Grant, spoke briefly, praising the peace at Appomattox reuniting the na tion. Rev. Richard H. Lee, a kinsman of R. E. Lee, spoke in the same vein. William A. Hart, director of adver tising, E. I. DuPont Company, pro ducers of Sunset at Appomattox, told the story of how the film, was made. Conrad L. Wirth, Director, National Park Service, thanked the DuPont Company for this documen tary contribution. Sunset at Appomattox will be televised nationally on DuPonts Cavalcade of America program, over ABC network, Tuesday night, Oct. 20. We understand WLVA - TV, in Lynchburg carries this program at 730 P. M. Attending the luncheon and the Premiere ... from Appomattox were r Mr. and Mrs. W. M. Abbitt, Mr. and Mrs. Chas. T. Moses, Judge and Mrs. Joel W. Flood, Mr. and Mrs. H. A. Gurney, Mr. and Mrs. D. T. Robert son, Mr. and Mrs. George Abbitt, Jr. C. W. Smith, Mr. and Mrs. J. A. Burke, Mr. and Mrs. C. T. document.text: The good rain came in such good time. Some of the farm ers have finished planting to bacco over the first time, but the weather keeps so cool real ly cold. Plenty frost first  second mornings in June, A rare thing. The wheat crop will soon be ready to harvest. It looks very good in the field. Prof. Wilkins and Mr. Hud gins are giving some splendid talks and information on agri culture at Pettys Fork School House e v e r y Wed. night Everybody should attend. Last Friday was a holiday but I guess the farmers had the hardest day as there was a to bacco season. Mr. G. P. Martin and his mother, Mrs. J. E. Martin, o Roanoke, motored to the home of J. A. document.text: The Baby Blue Hornets are also undefeated after two starts. They won from the V. E. S. Jayvees by a 20 to 7 score, and downed Nel son County H. S. Jayvees, 39 to 0. In the V. E. S. game, Steve Runkle scored two touchdowns and Carroll Ferguson one, to lead the junior varsity to its first victory. On de fense, Jack Henry, Charles Crawley, Palmer Moore and James Doss were outstanding. On offense, Eddie Car ter, a fullback, gained a lot of yardage for the junior varsity. On Tuesday afternoon, the Balby Blue Hornets walloped the Nelson County J. V. team by a score of 39 to 0. Frank Phelps scored two touchdowns, Steve Runkle  two touchdowns, Ronnie Mann one, and Tommy Catlett one. The Baby Blue Hornets will play the E. C. document.text: The Appomattox High School Blue Hornets football team has drilled this week in the hope of running up their third straight victory Fri day when at 800 oclock they meet a good Virginia Episcopal School, of Lynchburg, team a t the Town Park in the annual local Homecom ing game. The Blue Hornets won their Sec ond victory last Friday, when they downed Randolph-Henry H. S. by a 14 to 3 cote, here. Burl Clements  kicked a field goal for Randolph- Henry to put his team ahead 3 to 0 in the secoiW quarter. However, in the second half, the Blue Hornets started rolling, and with Freddie Mitchell, Raymond Msassie, Leon Edmonds and Arnold Whitehead do ing the ball carrying, they pushed over two touchdowns. Raymond Mass.de made the first and Freddie Mitchell the second. Leon Edmunds made both extra points. On defense Joey George, Dennis Drinkard, Toots Carter, Charles Crawley, Palmer Moore, Randy Almond, Richard Rob inson and Terrell Martin played well. Coach Gordon Bragg says that this weeks game will be a good teat for his team, stating that they will be meeting a heavy -team of older boys.

document.text: The Appomattox Hfigh School football team won its third straight game here Friday night, defeating Virginia Episcopal School, 21 to 18. The game was a wide-open affair, with both teams moving the ball well. It was the A. H. S. homecom ing game. The Blue Hornets showed a very good passing attack, scering all three of its touchdowns on passes. Appomattox players scoring were Toots Garter on a pass from Fred die Mitchell Toots Carter on a pass from Raymond Ferguson Ray mond Massie on a pass from Fred die Mitchell. The Blue Hornets al so scored a safety when Dan Cole- Iman and Toots Garter tackled the V. E. S- quarterback in the end zone for 2 points. The only extra  point made was on a pass . from Leon Edmunds to Raymond Fergu- I son. On defense for the Blue Hornets the following players were outstand ing Raymond Massie, Dan Coleman, Palmer Moore, James Doss, Dennis Drinkard, Richard Robinson, Terrell Martin and Charles Crawley. On offense,, Freddie Mitchells passing and RLhard Robinsons kicking kept the Hornets in the game. Rob inson had one kick of 60 yards, go ing out on the one yard line. The Blue Hornets will meet Nel son County Governors here at the Town Ball Park Friday at 800 P. M. This will be the first league game for A. H. S. Nelson County H. IS. has won two games in the dis- I trict, and now leads the league. This should be another fine game, with perhaps the district title at stake.

document.text: State and Federal government are getting  cady to use local elec tion machinery for the registration of men following the enactment by the Congress of draft legislation. A draft bill has already passed in the Senate, and is now bejng debated in the House. It is roughly estimated that Registration Day will take place in about fifteen d a n after the. draft bill is passed by both. housed, -of Congress and signed by the Pres ident. . Information concerning the pro posed Registration and Draft baa been received by Charles Crawley, secretary of the Appomattox County Elec tor ial Board, CTW, Sftifth, co. unty clerk, and W, M Abbith, Com mons wealth attorney. They are mak ing a study ofwhat will have to ba done to expedite the registration. They are now making a preliminary survey to ascertain approximately how many registration cards will bo needed in Appomattox county, and as soon as required Will assemble the regular election jtadgm to plan steps to comply with such draft, law as may be adopted by Congress. However, the above men are not Connected with any county draft board. No draft board! have been eet up yet.. document.text: On Tuesday of next week, Appo mattox town voters will select a mayor and a town council for a two year term. Mayor C. S. Mc- pearmon has no opposition for re- election. All of the incumbent mem bers of the town council are seek ing re-election. There is a vacancy on the council at this time, no one having been named to fill the place vacated in February by Charles Crawley, who resigned to accept a federal position. Ilhe incumbent councilmen are G. F. Abbitt, Jr.,. J. C. Caldwell, F. L. Murphy, C. L. McDcarmon and C. H. Robinson. Two yidditional candidates tare J. T. Irby and C. C. Poe. Six are to be chosen, the new term to begin September 1. At the regular meeting of the town council Monday night, it was announced that the State may re surface Church Street thiB summer. Lee-Graat Avenue is already being resurfaced.
